description: First attested in 1526, from Middle English abrogat (“abolished”), from Latin abrogātus, perfect passive participle of abrogō (“repeal”), formed from ab (“away”) + rogō (“ask, inquire, propose”). See rogation.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Abrogated; abolished. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]

verbs.description: abrogate (third-person singular simple present abrogates, present participle abrogating, simple past and past participle abrogated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To annul by an authoritative act; to abolish by the authority of the maker or her or his successor; to repeal; — applied to the repeal of laws, decrees, ordinances, the abolition of customs, etc. [First attested in the early 16th century.]
examples: But let us look a little further, and see whether the New Testament abrogates what we see so frequently used in the Old.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put an end to; to do away with. [First attested in the early 16th century.]
(molecular biology, transitive) To block a process or function.
